H I G H L I G H T S
• Nanostructure or microstructure alone hardly enhance critical heat flux. • Hierarchical structures showed a synergetic enhancement on critical heat flux. • Smaller dry spot controlled by surface capillarity was more advantageous to the enhancement.
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Critical heat flux Accident-tolerant fuel cladding Surface roughness Capillary wicking
A B S T R A C T
This study aimed to improve the thermal safety of accident-tolerant fuel (ATF) cladding by enhancing the pool boiling critical heat flux (CHF) through control of the nano/microscale roughness of ATF-functional Cr- and CrAl-coated surfaces. To diversify the surface structures at the nano/microscale, we ground the surface to achieve the typical roughness range of a nuclear fuel cladding and then deposited the ATF candidate materials of Cr and CrAl on the ground surface. 17 test surfaces were fabricated by grouping three types of surface structures: microstructure, nanostructure, and nano/microstructure. The structural feature was parametrically categorized based on the arithmetic roughness height Ra at microscale and the surface area ratio rn at nanoscale. While Ra was observed to influence both the nucleate boiling efficiency and CHF, rn was not capable of enhancing them both exclusively. Nonetheless, a synergistic effect of Ra and rn on the CHF was observed. The CHF values of microstructure, nanostructure, and nano/microstructure were enhanced by 19%, 9%, and 79%, respectively. A capillary wicking experiment showed that an increase in surface roughness leads to a decrease in the dry area; therefore, a potential increase in the liquid area fraction of the boiling surface contributes to additional evaporation.

sections.heading: 1.1. Background
sections.text:
The primary function of the accident-tolerant fuel (ATF) claddings deployed in nuclear power plant systems is to significantly reduce the high-temperature steam reaction under severe accident conditions, thereby mitigating hydrogen generation [1]. After an elaborate screening of the design strategies applicable to ATF cladding [2,3], coating an oxidation-resistant microlayer on the outer surfaces of existing Zr-based alloys has been identified as a promising method for
short-term development and application. This method has been considered because maintaining the existing Zr-based alloys with a surface coating does not require considerable changes in the neutron absorption efficiency and thermal-hydraulic feedback unlike the changes required when completely replacing the Zr-based alloys.
Incorporating minimal changes in addition to enhancing the oxidation resistance has been recognized as acceptable with respect to the technical requirements of the ATF cladding system. Nevertheless, the research community concerned with enhancing the boiling performance on modified surfaces has reported that a considerable enhancement in the critical heat flux (CHF) in nuclear fuel cladding

A recent RELAP5-3D simulation [8], for instance, showed that even a 10% enhancement in the CHF of ATF claddings could potentially reduce the peak cladding temperature in a reactivity-initiated accident (RIA). Using direct current (DC) magnetron sputtering, Seo et al. [12] fabricated FeCrAl-coated layers having different surface roughnesses. They observed that the CHF of the FeCrAl-coated surfaces was enhanced up to 42% and attributed it to an increased roughness factor which augmented the length of the triple contact line for additional rewetting. Son et al. In contrast, it is difficult to enhance the CHF if the ATF-functional surfaces are finished very smoothly. For example, Jo et al. [16] coated Cr and FeCrAl over a Zr-based surface using a cold spray technique and then polished the coated surfaces again to remove the structural features. For a decrease in the surface roughness up to 10−2 µm, they observed no significant change in the CHF.
Besides the surface effect on the CHF, recent quenching experiments especially focused on a Cr-coated surface also show that a change in the surface characteristics affects the quench performance. Lee et al. [17] observed that the quench duration of a Cr-coated niobium (Nb) surface is longer than that of a non-coated surface despite the higher surface roughness and larger heat capacity of the Cr-coated surface. According to Ebrahim et al. [18], the larger the heat capacity, the slower is the transition from film boiling to nucleate boiling. Seshadri and Shirvan [19] evaluated the quench performance of fresh and oxidized Cr-, FeCrAl-, and Mo-coated surfaces by measuring the surface wettability and capillary wicking capability. Before oxidation, the quench duration was shortest for the FeCrAl-coated surface, whereas, after oxidation, the surface wettability and capillary wicking of the Cr-coated surface significantly improved, resulting in a better quench performance than the FeCrAl-coated surface. Considering the experimental findings from recent studies, it is obvious that the surface characteristic of the ATFfunctional surface is one of key engineering factors capable of affecting both the CHF and the quench.

sections.heading: 1.2. Motivation and objective
sections.text:
To define the type of surface parameter that is essential for enhancing the CHF and to describe the issues that still remain unclear, it is necessary to obtain a relation between the surface characteristics and the CHF. Considering that the key surface factors influencing the CHF are known to be surface wettability (quantified by θa) and surface roughness (quantified by Ra) [20–22], we collected the available data on CHF, θa, and Ra measured on the ATF-functional surfaces and plotted these in Fig. 1. In Fig. 1(a), although the CHF tends to decrease with θa, the overall trend with the surface wettability can hardly be understood. Especially, the parametric comparison between the contact angle and CHF is limited to a superhydrophilic region because the contact angle quantity cannot distinguish the surface wettability when θa = 0° [15]. Moreover, the existence of excessive CHF outliers along θa aggravates the correlation between the surface wettability and CHF. In contrast, an improved correlation is observed between the surface roughness and CHF: the higher the surface roughness, the higher is the CHF (Fig. 1(b)). In the global context, the positive relation between Ra and the CHF is understood based on the previous findings demonstrating that an increase in the surface roughness augments the liquid/solid contact lines [23] and provides more capillary channels [24], thereby supplying more cooling liquid to evaporate the contact lines.
However, an evaluation of the CHF for various surface roughnesses defined at different scales (i.e., nano-, micro-, and nano/microscales) is still lacking toward understanding the local behavior of the surface roughness with respect to the CHF. This is because most of the previous studies tend to introduce as-received/as-machined ATF surfaces [9–11,13,25,26] for the evaluation of the CHF rather than systematically defining the fabrication parameters during the polishing, grinding, and deposition processes for nano/microscale roughness
control. Although a few studies have reported the CHF of roughnesscontrolled surfaces for ATF application by polishing Cr- and FeCrAlcoated surfaces [16], controlling the deposition process of FeCrAl [12], and controlling the grinding/deposition processes of Cr [15] and Cr and FeCrAl [14], these studies provide a limited understanding of the separate effects of the surface roughness with respect to the nano- and microscales. Thus, it is necessary to establish a design basis for the ATF cladding surface in need of nano/microscale roughness control. Moreover, it would potentially assist ATF cladding developers in understanding how controlling the surface roughness affects the CHF.
In this regard, this study experimentally investigates the effect of multiscale roughness of the ATF-functional surface on the CHF and clarifies which roughness scale and combination are effective in enhancing the CHF. We control the multiscale roughness by either polishing or grinding a substrate surface and subsequently depositing the ATF candidate materials (Cr and CrAl are selected for this study) over the surface. After grouping the fabricated surfaces according to the surface roughness defined at nano-, micro-, and nano/microscales, the effect of the different surface roughness scales on the CHF is investigated. Moreover, we characterize the capillary wicking capability such that it is possible to observe the contact line behavior under room condition, which would thereby indicate the underlying cause of the CHF being different for each surface.

sections.heading: 2. Multi-scale roughness control at the level of the nuclear fuel cladding surface
2.1. Stepwise fabrication of the surface structures at nano/microscale: Surface grinding and coating
sections.text:
Various types of surface structures (e.g., nano-/micro-roughened [12–15,24], nano-/micro-porous [27–29], and nano-/micro-patterned [21,30–32]) have been introduced in the past to improve the pool boiling performance. However, it is challenging to apply porous and patterned surfaces to nuclear fuel cladding despite their considerable benefits in boiling enhancement. This is because these structures are vulnerable to surface aging due to the significantly enlarged surface area ratio at nano/microscale. In addition, it is technically challenging to fabricate their high-scale structures with the ATF materials. Therefore, the remaining options have been considered in this study. Based on the illustrations shown in Fig. 2, the structural features of each surface and their potential effects on the CHF are briefly explained as follows.
• Type 1 (Fig. 2(a)): The ATF materials are uniformly deposited on a smooth surface, thereby finishing the apparent surface at nanoscale without any microscale features. This type of surface structure is unlikely to affect the CHF because the nanoscale roughness seems to be too low to remarkably improve the capillary action. • Type 2 (Fig. 2(b)): The conventional method of grinding the surface generates a considerable number of unidirectional grooved lines, each of which plays the role of a capillary channel [15,24]. This surface finishing is similar to those being performed in existing nuclear fuel claddings. The apparent structure demonstrates a low microscale feature with a roughness height (Ra)< 1.0 µm. • Type 3 (Fig. 2(c)): By depositing the ATF materials over the intrinsic microstructure in Type 2, the apparent feature of the surface becomes hierarchical at nano/microscale, which results in an increase in the surface area ratio to a value higher than those of the other types. As an increase in the surface area ratio amplifies the liquid/solid adhesive or capillary forces [32,33], it is expected that the CHF is more enhanced than those in the other types. • Type 4 (Fig. 2(d)): The surface of Type 1 is smoothened by polishing the apparent nanostructure. This type of surface has been recognized as one of the most promising for ATF cladding applications because the smooth surface minimizes the area that is in contact
with the primary coolant, thereby mitigating surface oxidation [34]. In contrast to the possible gain in terms of the integrity of the surface, the structural effect of the smooth feature on the CHF is negligible regardless of the surface wettability [21,35]. Likewise, Jo et al. [16] observed that polishing Cr- and FeCrAl-coated surfaces does not lead to any changes in the CHF despite a slight variation in the surface wettability.
Among the abovementioned surface types, we adopted Types 1, 2, and 3 and did not consider Type 4 as its smooth surface would not be effective for CHF enhancement. A modification process in two steps was performed to categorize the scales of the apparent structures into nano-, micro-, and nano/microscale. First, to generate different intrinsic microstructures before coating the surface with ATF materials, the test surfaces were ground with different grits of sandpaper. The purpose of this process was to limit the roughness range to an engineering scale applicable to nuclear fuel cladding, in which the surface oxidation under normal operating conditions is not an issue because the surface roughness is close to the technical standard (Ra ≈ 0.3 μm) of the Zrbased alloys in commercial use. Typically, a higher grit number (having a lower particle diameter) leads to a lower surface roughness. Therefore, relatively high grits of sandpaper, including 800, 600, 400, and 320, were considered. Moreover, the surface was carefully ground along a single direction to generate unidirectional scratches, which provided abundant grooved channels at microscale. Based on Darcy′s law that accounts for the permeable characteristic of a liquid along a porous medium [36], these grooved channels can drive the capillary flow because microscale flow channels bear small cross-sectional areas, which can cause a viscous pressure drop for a specific distance [14,15,24].
The second step was to generate nanostructures over the intrinsic microstructure. Among the ATF candidate materials such as FeCrAl, Cr, CrAl, and SiC, we considered Cr and CrAl as the coating materials. Experimentally, Cr- [37,38] and CrAl- [39] coated Zr-based alloys have guaranteed an excellent adhesion integrity even under high-temperature steam oxidation. Owing to the poor adhesion strength of FeCrAl and SiC coatings with Zr-based claddings, these materials have been considered as alternatives to replace the cladding body itself rather than being used as a protective coating [3]. Two coating techniques, DC magnetron sputtering and arc ion plating, were performed to deposit Cr and CrAl on the ground surfaces, respectively. These coating techniques demonstrate a high degree of freedom for the use of the metallic material as the coating target. All the coating conditions of Cr and CrAl are summarized in Table 1.
During the DC magnetron sputtering of Cr, the growth mechanism of the metal film depends on the sputtering parameters such as substrate temperature, inert gas pressure, exposure time, and DC power [40]. Among these parameters, the substrate temperature significantly affects the diffusion of adatoms, and this process plays a role in determining the size of the agglomerated clusters. Typically, a high substrate temperature actuates the diffusion of adatoms, which, in turn, forms compact Cr clusters at nanoscale. This implies that controlling the substrate temperature contributes to noticeable changes in the apparent nano/microstructures. Within the allowable operation limit of the sputtering facility, the substrate temperature was set to 25 °C, 150 °C, 300 °C, and 600 °C to diversify the morphology and roughness of the coated surface.
The CrAl-coated surface was fabricated by the ATF Technology Development Division at the Korea Atomic Energy Research Institute. The coating developers at the institute determined the relative composition of the CrAl alloy by testing its effect on the ATF cladding primary functions (i.e., high-temperature oxidation resistance and mechanical strength). Representatively, they reported that coating the CrAl alloy (Cr 85 wt%: Al 15 wt%) on a Zr-based cladding enables the coated surface to be more resistant to high-temperature steam conditions as well as normal operating conditions [41]. Under oxidation
conditions, CrAl forms Al2O3 over the coated surface, and so the protective layer consisting of Al2O3 significantly delays further oxidation [42]. In this study, we used a single composition of the CrAl alloy (Cr 80 wt%: Al 20 wt%), which has been verified by the KAERI, thereby focusing only on its surface characteristic. By setting the power condition in the arc ion plating process 32 times higher (4,800 W) than that of DC magnetron sputtering (150 W), a surface roughness approximately seven times higher was obtained in the CrAl-coated surface. A high-scale roughness of this surface could not be achieved with DC
magnetron sputtering due to the capacity limitation of the power supply. Further details on the arc ion plating technique are provided in [38]. While DC sputtering technique exhibits an inherent disadvantage of coating a large area, other relevant fabrication techniques such as PVD and cold spray coating may be applicable for the practical large dimension of the nuclear fuel cladding. Feasibility study of applying these techniques will be valuable in diversifying their applicability in near future.

sections.heading: 2.2. Observation of the coated layer and surface morphology
sections.text:
After 1 h of sputtering, a Cr layer of approximately 1.5 μm thickness was formed with fine columnar grains (Fig. 3(a)). The mapping result of energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) also indicates that an interlayer between the Pt and Fe layers comprises a relatively higher composition of Cr compared to others. Fig. 3(b) shows that a thick CrAl layer of approximately 70 μm thickness was formed during the arc ion plating process. Using the EDS line detection method, it was further confirmed that Cr and Al were mainly distributed inside the CrAl layer, while Fe rarely existed. It is important to note that both the Cr and CrAl layers were not porous except for isolated microdefects along the CrAl layer. Therefore, it is evident that the boiling performance depends only on the ‘surface’ characteristics (e.g., roughness and wettability) for a particular thickness of the coated layer.
As shown in Fig. 3(c) and (d), the compositions of the major coating elements measured on the Cr- and CrAl-coated surfaces were almost similar to the design values shown in Table 1. Although the oxygen of 2.29 wt% was measured on the Cr-coated surface, its contribution to the total amount seems negligible compared to the dominant contribution of the Cr of 97.71 wt%. Likewise, on the CrAl-coated surface, the actual composition of the CrAl coating (82.92 wt%: Al 17.08 wt%) changed slightly from the design value of the CrAl alloy (Cr 80 wt%: Al 20 wt%).

sections.heading: 3.1. Measurement of surface roughness and wettability
sections.text:
For a quantitative analysis of the morphological changes, the
surface roughness was measured by an atomic force microscope (AFM) (XE-100 model) in which the noncontact mode was used for facilitating a high-resolution nanoscale measurement (≈ 0.01 nm). To distinguish the raw configurations of the surface roughness values between the nano/microscales, the roughness profiles were obtained at different AFM resolutions: 30 × 30 μm2 and 5 × 5 μm2 for micro- and nanoscales, respectively (Fig. 5). Similar to the observations in the SEM images, the profile at microscale (Fig. 5(a)) is observed to be the roughest on the CrAl-coated surfaces among all the coated surfaces. The surface roughness values of the bare and Cr-coated surfaces are approximately two times lower than that of the CrAl-coated surface. The difference in the microscale roughness profiles of the bare and Crcoated surfaces is almost negligible. At the nanolevel (Fig. 5(b)), a frequent peak-to-peak variation along the roughness profile is observed on the Cr-coated surface; however, such a variation is hardly observed on the other surfaces. Among the various roughness parameters, we measured the arithmetic roughness height Ra and the nanoscale surface area ratio rn at the AFM resolutions of 30 × 30 μm2 and 5 × 5 μm2, respectively. Here, Ra and rn physically mean the average of the absolute height values along the sampling length and the ratio of the actual area over the projected area, respectively. The mathematical expression of each parameter is shown in Fig. 5.
Importantly, as the roughness features cannot be perfectly uniform over the ground and sputtered surfaces, using the roughness value measured only at a single position may be too irrational to signify the representative nature of the surfaces. To avoid this overgeneralization, the uniformity of the micro/nanoscale surface roughness was evaluated with repeatable measurements at different positions. As shown in the inset histogram in Fig. 6(a), the measurements were repeated between as few as three times and as many as nine times. The repeatability error was calculated by dividing the standard deviation by an averaged value. Fig. 6(b) shows that the repeatability error in Ra is under 22%, which is higher than the 6% maximum error in rn. These repeatability errors are considered during the comparison of the CHF data in Section 4.2. Considering that the uniformity of the grooved lines at microscale is relatively lower than that of the nanoscale surface area ratio, introducing a reliable engineering process to regularly pattern the microgrooved lines over the metal surface is necessary in the future.
The overall trends of the measured Ra and rn are shown in Fig. 6(b).
First, Ra increases as the grit number of the sandpaper decreases. When the same grit number is used, Ra hardly varies in spite of changing the substrate temperature for the sputtering process. As an exceptional case, the surface roughness of CrAl-G800-T250 increases significantly up to 7.8 times compared to the Cr-G800-T25/150/300/600 cases. This result can be attributed to the fact that a sputtering power 32 times higher than that of the other cases was applied for the CrAl coating. Second, a decrease in the substrate temperature causes an increase in rn (except for the cases of Cr-M-T600 and Cr-G800-T600) and scarcely affects Ra. This signifies that controlling the sputtering conditions dominated the changing nanoscale features more than augmenting the microscale roughness. Based on the observed trends, it is evident that the grinding and coating processes enable the categorization of the surface structure into micro- and nanoscales, respectively.
In addition to the surface roughness, a contact angle was measured to quantify the surface wettability. Fig. 7(a) shows the measurement system of the contact angle, which includes an EasyDrop 100 goniometer. A water droplet having a volume of 5 μL was first generated at the end of the syringe. To exclude the effect of impingement of the droplet with the surface while measuring the contact angle (which causes unintended rebound of the droplet [44]), the test surface slowly moved upward and touched the water droplet. Instantly, the liquid/ solid contact line began spreading over the surface and stopped at its equilibrium state. After confirming that the contact line did not move anymore, the apparent contact angle θa was measured by the imaging system of the EasyDrop 100 goniometer.
Fig. 7(b) shows that, after coating Cr and CrAl, the surface wettability changes from hydrophilic (60–70°) to superhydrophilic (≈0°). To check which of the roughness parameters out of Ra and rn mainly affect θa, we compare the relations in Fig. 7(c) and (d), respectively, with the available data of Ra, rn, and θa obtained from the studies that report a change in the wettability due to modifications in metallic surfaces. While the effect of Ra on θa seems to be unclear (Fig. 7(c)), either oxidation, anodization or an increase in rn enables the surface to be more hydrophilic (Fig. 7(c) and (d)). Oxidation [45] increases the liquid/solid surface adhesion and the existence of the nanostructure [15,33] enlarges the nanoscale surface area; both of them play a role in further attracting the liquid to spread over the surface. Similarly, it is observed that on differently roughened surfaces, θa hardly varies with
changes in Ra [24], whereas the surface wettability is significantly improved by an augmentation of the nanoscale feature rather than a variation in Ra [28]. Therefore, it is deduced that the superhydrophilicity of the coated surfaces is mainly the result of the generation of the nanostructures.

sections.heading: 3.2. Measurement of the capillary wicking capability
sections.text:
There are several ways to characterize the surface capillarity, i.e., capillary rise [46,47], hemi-spreading [48], wickability [32,49], and receding capillary flow [50]. Among these, we used the characterization method of the receding capillary flow, which is capable of mimicking the in-situ capillary wicking behavior [50,51]. As described in our previous study [50], this method considers the contribution of the vapor recoil pressure to the receding motion of an in-situ triple contact line. It enables the measurement of the size of an expanding dry area that varies with the nano/microscale surface roughness and wettability. With respect to the CHF, a smaller size of the dry area indicates a higher liquid area fraction occupied along the bubble footprints [52], which
implies that more heat flux is necessary to bear the additional evaporation.
Fig. 8(a) shows the experimental apparatus; it consists of an air supply line (connected to an air compressor), a syringe needle for air impingement (inner diameter of 0.52 mm), a test assembly, a highspeed camera, and a light source (both of which are located outside the photograph). The design values for the experiment are specified in Fig. 8(b). In the experimental procedure, we first spread sufficient deionized water (≈20 °C) to entirely cover the test surface. Over the wet surface, a jet of air compressed to 0.4 MPa was shot from the syringe needle. Then, the liquid competed with the air jet drying the surface such that the pressure of the jet rapidly drove the flow of the bulk liquid that is not captured by the surface structure, while the liquid that is absorbed inside the surface structure slowly receded against the driving pressure.
A visual observation shows an extremely different drying behavior between the bare and coated surfaces (Fig. 8(c)): the bare surface is rapidly dried out without any wicking region, whereas the coated surface that is capable of wicking the liquid resists being totally dried
out by further competing along the liquid/solid/air contact line. Here, since the major focus is on comparing the delayed growth behavior of the dry area between the roughness-controlled surfaces, we quantified the expansion rate of the dry area, dAdry/dt, and calculated the dry area, Adry, using a reference time of 5.3 ms at which the diameter of the dry area of a bare surface reaches a capillary length Lc = =σ ρ g/ 2.5mmlv l for saturated water. The quantified data of dAdry/dt and Adry are shown in Table 2, and the result is discussed in Section 4.3.
Based on the measured data with respect to the roughness parameters, apparent contact angle, and capillary wicking capability, a test matrix is organized in Table 2. There were 17 cases in all, which were categorized under three types of structural features, i.e., microstructure, nanostructure, and nano/microstructure. The microstructure group, in which the surfaces were not coated, was used to investigate the effect of the microscale roughness Ra on the CHF. The role of this group was to provide the bare CHF data of the intrinsic microstructure for comparing the CHF gain on the coated surfaces. The nanostructure group, in which the surfaces were not ground, was used to investigate whether the nanoscale surface area ratio rn, excluding the microscale features, could enhance the CHF. The results can reveal the effects of controlling the sputtering conditions on the CHF gain. Finally, the nano/microstructure group, in which the surfaces were ground and coated, was used to investigate the synergetic effect of the microscale roughness and nanoscale surface area ratio on the CHF. The major focus of this group was to estimate the amount of CHF enhancement that could be achieved compared to the other groups.

sections.heading: 3.3. Measurement of the pool boiling curve up to CHF
sections.text:
The design of the pool boiling apparatus shown in Fig. 9(a) is similar to that used in our previous study [15]. Its design for this study was slightly modified to incorporate some changes in the insulation of the test section (Fig. 9(b)), which generated a different boiling trend between bare surfaces. The pool boiling chamber (shown in Fig. 9(a)) made of a polycarbonate was filled with deionized water of high electrical resistivity (18.5 MΩ-cm), which ensured that the electricity leakage through the deionized water was negligible. Four immersion heaters were consistently operated to retain the deionized water saturated under atmospheric pressure. Before supplying the DC power into the test section, the saturated water was degassed, until noncondensable gases were invisible inside the pool boiling chamber. Fig. 9(b) shows the assembling of the test section with a test sample: a flat plate of 45 mm length, 10 mm width, and 2 mm thickness. Out of the total length of 45 mm, the heating length was only 25 mm as 10 mm was used for electrical contact with the copper holders at both ends. Thus, the effective heat transfer area was 25 × 10 mm2. Importantly, the 5 mm gap between the test sample and the supporting mount made of polyetheretherketone (PEEK) was filled with a liquid epoxy (a mixture of SamplKwickTM 20-3566 and 20-3568), which was completely solidified after approximately 2 h. The insulation obtained through this solidification of the liquid epoxy guarantees a larger contact area with the test sample than a solid-to-solid contact between PEEK and the test sample, thereby reducing the heat loss through the narrow gaps around
the test sample. To supply a stable heat flux to the test sample made of stainless steel grade 304, Joule′s direct heating method was implemented with a DC power supply (1200 A / 30 V). Based on the design of the test section, the resistance of the test sample was calculated to be 1.55 × 10−3 Ω, which was approximately 103 times higher than that of the copper connector (8.18 × 10−7 Ω). This implies that a voltage drop occurred predominantly along the test sample rather than the copper connector, and thus, all the DC power supplied was used to generate the resistance

The nanostructure group (Cr-M-T25/150/300/600) having a negligible Ra of 0.038 µm shows similar trends for the CHF and nucleate boiling despite a variation in rn (1.16–1.40). No significant enhancement in boiling on the nanostructure surface is observed. In the micro/nanostructure group (Cr-G800-T25/150/300/600), by changing the grinding condition from M to G800, the CHF slightly increases with Ra (0.09–0.123 µm) although the nucleate boiling hardly changes. Upon controlling Ra up to 0.258 µm with a fixed rn of 1.24 for the surface group Cr-G800/600/400/320-T150, it is observed that both the CHF and the nucleate boiling improves.

Fig. 12 compares the CHF enhancement ratio of the surfaces coated with the ATF candidate materials, including Cr [10,13–15], FeCrAl [12,14], ZrSi2 [11], and the present data. In Fig. 12(a), it is observed that the CHF is enhanced as the surface roughness increases, regardless of the surface coating. Most of the CHF data reported till date show an enhancement up to approximately 50% within the roughness range of 0.3 µm. Although more enhancement in the CHF can be achieved if one further increases the surface roughness above 0.3 µm, it might be unfavorable for the oxidation resistance of the coated surface. Note that the roughness value of 0.3 µm used in this study is not a technical standard but a typical engineering value obtained from conventional nuclear fuel claddings; thus, the value can be changed according to different engineering or regulatory points of view.
Focusing on the trend of the present data, the CHF enhancement trend in Fig. 12(b) can be separated into three groups based on the surface engineering processes, i.e., grinding, sputtering, grinding and sputtering. The extent of the enhancement is lower in the sputtered surfaces than in the ground and sputtered surfaces. Grinding the surface before sputtering effectively enhances the CHF beyond the upper bound of the CHF enhancement achievable on the sputtered surfaces. In contrast, when the surface is sputtered by Cr without a grinding process, the CHF is marginally enhanced up to 9%, regardless of the variation in rn. Considering the extreme thermal-hydraulic conditions in the nuclear core, a CHF enhancement of 9% is very low. Therefore, it would be
difficult to achieve a meaningful DNB gain in the ATF-functional claddings using the sputtering process exclusively without the grinding process.

The effect of Ra on the CHF is shown in Fig. 13(a). On the ground surfaces (BareG800/600/400/320), a decrease in the grit number of sandpaper, which increases Ra at microscale, results in an enhancement of the CHF by 19%. This minimal enhancement has been typically observed in case of hydrophilic ground or polished metal surfaces. In numerous experimental observations [15,23,24], it was observed that a higher surface roughness augments the length of the triple contact lines [23] and even activates capillary wicking [15,24], thereby enhancing the CHF monotonically with surface roughness. Thus, with a lower grit number of the sandpaper, a higher Ra and a higher CHF enhancement are achieved.
The effect of rn on the CHF is shown in Fig. 13(b). When the coating materials are deposited on a mirror-polished surface having Ra = 0.038 µm with varied substrate temperatures (Cr-M-T25/150/ 300/600), the CHF demonstrates a minimal enhancement of up to 9%. Moreover, a small variation of 6–9% in the CHF is observed as rn increases from 1.16 to 1.42. Similarly, Son et al. [13] observed a minimal enhancement of 6% on a Cr-coated surface despite increases in rn and
wettability. These results imply that the effect of rn on the CHF is almost negligible if microscale features are not present in the surface. Indeed, rn starts to affect the CHF, when an intrinsic microstructure is provided by surface grinding (Cr-G800-T25/150/300/600). In this case, the CHF is enhanced from 9 to 46% for a similar variation in rn (it increases from 1.16 to 1.42). Therefore, it is evident that although a lower substrate temperature in the sputtering process generates a higher rn, its effect on the CHF depends on the existence of microscale roughness.
Lastly, the combination of Ra and rn creates a synergistic effect on the CHF, which is shown in Fig. 13(a). When a fixed rn of 1.24 is applied to differently ground surfaces (Cr-G800/600/400/320-T150), a variation in Ra from 0.090 to 0.258 µm enhances the CHF by up to 79%. Moreover, in case of CrAl-G800-T250, the highest Ra value of 0.539 µm leads to further enhancement of the CHF (110%). Considering the relationship between the surface structure and CHF, it is emphasized that the surface coating process must be conducted on a ground surface and not on a mirror surface in the light of improving the thermal safety of the ATF cladding.

sections.heading: 4.3. Analysis of CHF enhancement with capillary wicking phenomenon
sections.text:
According to the previous findings that encompass surface characterization [32,47,49], in-situ observation of a liquid/vapor distribution [58], and corresponding theoretical models [23,24,59,60], it has been established that one of the key mechanisms enhancing the CHF on roughness-controlled surfaces originates from the capillary wicking phenomenon, which is capable of passively supplying the cooling liquid responsible for additional evaporation. In particular, the mechanism implies that the longer the imbibition length of the capillary flow, the higher is the liquid area fraction over the boiling surface so that the CHF can be enhanced with the corresponding portion of the liquid area fraction. Based on this demonstration, we analyze an underlying cause of enhancing the CHF on roughness-controlled surfaces through the experimental observation of the growth behavior of the dry spot
characterized in Section 3.2. Fig. 14 shows that although a dramatic variation in Adry with Ra is not observed for a narrow range of Ra (0.1–0.5 µm), Adry tends to gradually decrease as Ra increases. Moreover, an increase in rn in addition to Ra contributes to a smaller Adry because the nanostructure augments the liquid/solid contact line, thereby assisting the liquid to adhere to the surface [33]. In particular, a significant delay in the liquid receding is observed for CrAl-G800-T250, owing to its two times higher Ra compared to the others. Based on this observation, it is noteworthy that augmenting the surface roughness and adding the nanoscale feature on the rougher surface are beneficial for further enhancing the capillarity, which, in turn, provides an increased resistance to recede from the expansion of the dry area. Furthermore, in comparison with the CHF (Fig. 15), it is observed that the decreasing trend of Adry with Ra is inversely proportional to an increase in the CHF. This correlation emphasizes that the size of the dry spot, controlled by the surface capillarity, is significantly related to triggering the CHF. Under a pool boiling condition, Park et al. [61] likewise observed that a reduction in the bubble base diameter on structured surfaces is favorable for the successful rewetting and corresponding enhancement of CHF. Considering the similarity of the result, we infer that the capillary wicking behavior characterized in this study has a potential linkage to the actual behavior of bubble dry spots.
To link Adry estimated under a room adiabatic condition to a liquid/ vapor phase distribution under actual boiling conditions, we first simplify a near-CHF boiling structure on a rough surface as shown in Fig. 16(a). According to the in-situ observations of the boiling structure using infrared (IR) thermography [62] and synchrotron X-ray imaging [58], the liquid/vapor phase distribution underneath the boiling bubbles merging with each other can be depicted by separating a bubble dry spot/patch and the surrounding wicked liquid inside a given bubble base meniscus (Fig. 16(b)). Then, the liquid area fraction, 1-α, with the bubble base area, Ab, is simply expressed as (Ab-Ads)/Ab, where Ads denotes the area of the bubble dry spot. Herein, Ads is replaced by Adry, assuming that the hydrodynamic behavior of the bubble dry spot (Ads) on the rough surface is analogous to the present observation of the areabased capillary wicking (Adry). Moreover, assuming that the bubble base diameter corresponds to the capillary length Lc = =σ ρ g/ 2.5mmlv l for saturated water, Ab is calculated to be 4.85 mm2. sections.heading: 4.4. Discussion and recommendations for future study
sections.text:
Based on the current observation and useful insights from recent studies, it is inferred that the CHF is significantly affected by the growth behavior of the dry spot resulting from the capillary wicking capability of engineered surfaces. Accordingly, the key to enhance the CHF of an engineered ATF-functional surface is to determine ways to delay the growth of the dry spots by controlling the surface roughness at nano/ microscale. In our experiment, no CHF maxima are observed within Ra ≈ 0.5 µm; the dry area consistently decreases as the surface roughness increases at least within the roughness range for ATF cladding applications. This provides mounting evidence that a higher surface roughness would be beneficial for achieving higher CHF in an ATF-functional surface, even though we have only observed it under a pool boiling condition. Moreover, considering that the dry area is smaller on a hierarchical structure (micro/nanostructure) than on independent structures (microstructure and nanostructure), this result further emphasizes the practical importance of hierarchically engineering the surface at nano/microscale to improve the thermal safety of the ATF cladding.
Although this study suggests a design basis for clarifying the role of the surface feature on the CHF of ATF claddings, the practical usage of the result would be limited to a laboratory-scale condition of atmospheric-pressure pool boiling on fresh-engineered surfaces. This is because the extreme thermal-hydraulic and water chemistry
environments in nuclear reactor cores mostly require high-pressure flow boiling on aged-engineered surfaces. Moreover, since an RIA leading to a sudden excursion in the thermal power alters the boiling curve and even the CHF [66], it is necessary to further consider a transient CHF rather than a steady-state CHF on the ATF cladding. The flow boiling CHF experiment coupled with the ATF candidate materials is notably lacking. Very recently, Lee et al. [25] reported that the steady-state and transient flow boiling CHF of an FeCrAl alloy is affected not by the surface characteristics but by the thermal property. However, since they used the FeCrAl alloy as a body material rather than systematically controlling its surface morphology at nano/microscale, the effect of the surface characteristics of the ATF claddings on the flow boiling CHF is not understood yet.
In terms of surface aging, a few studies have shown that the oxidation of the ATF-functional surfaces either preserves or even enhances
the CHF [9,11,67] and the quench performance [17,19]. Moreover, it has been confirmed that a nanoscale morphology of the Cr-coated surface is resistant to clogging during oxidation under 400 °C dry air [67]; thus, nanotechnology can be applied to the surface engineering of the ATF claddings. Nonetheless, under the water chemistry conditions in the primary loop of a nuclear power plant, the surface characteristics of the ATF cladding are inevitably affected by the cumulative deposition of Chalk River unidentified deposits (CRUD) in the region where the subcooled boiling occurs [6]. Considering all the aforementioned limitations, future studies need to evaluate the realistic effects of core thermal-hydraulic conditions (i.e., high-pressure flow boiling), accident conditions (i.e., RIA), and water chemistry (i.e., oxidation and CRUD formation) on the thermal safety of the ATF cladding.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusions
sections.text:
This study investigated the CHF of an ATF-functional surface by controlling the surface roughness at nano/microscale. To diversify the roughness value and scale, we fabricated a total of 17 roughness-controlled surfaces (four ground surface, twelve Cr-coated surfaces, and one CrAl-coated surface). Based on the measurements of the basic surface characteristics (Ra, rn, and θa), capillary wicking capability (Adry), and boiling parameters (HTC and CHF) of the surfaces, the effect of the nano/microscale roughness of the ATF-functional surface on the CHF was analyzed. The major findings are summarized as follows.
(1) As presented in Table 3, it was difficult to improve the nucleate boiling heat transfer by grinding or sputtering the surface exclusively. In contrast, hierarchically augmenting the surface structure resulted in a synergetic effect on the CHF as well as the nucleate boiling efficiency. The CHF showed an increasing trend within the current range of surface roughness (0.11–0.54 µm) without any maxima. (2) Importantly, enlarging the nanoscale surface area without the microscale feature was ineffective in enhancing the CHF. To resolve this limitation at least under the pool boiling condition, the apparent microstructure should be guaranteed an Ra of> 0.1 μm. Therefore, from the perspective of thermal engineering, depositing the ATF materials onto the smooth surface with a variation in the nanoscale features (not porous) can be ineffective in improving the thermal efficiency and safety of the nuclear fuel claddings. (3) Nevertheless, the nanoscale feature assisted by nuclear fuel cladding-level surface roughness (Ra ≈ 0.3 μm) could generate a capillary action, which was as much as the CHF enhancement. From the underlying relation between them, it was confirmed that a higher surface roughness and a more delayed growth in the dry area could result in a higher liquid area fraction, which was responsible for the additional evaporation of the wicked liquid inside the surface structures. The correlation between the dry area, the liquid area fraction, and the CHF was consistent with those reported previously.

metadata.abstractText: This study aimed to improve the thermal safety of accident-tolerant fuel (ATF) cladding by enhancing the pool boiling critical heat flux (CHF) through control of the nano/microscale roughness of ATF-functional Crand CrAl-coated surfaces. To diversify the surface structures at the nano/microscale, we ground the surface to achieve the typical roughness range of a nuclear fuel cladding and then deposited the ATF candidate materials of Cr and CrAl on the ground surface. 17 test surfaces were fabricated by grouping three types of surface structures: microstructure, nanostructure, and nano/microstructure. The structural feature was parametrically categorized based on the arithmetic roughness height Ra at microscale and the surface area ratio rn at nanoscale. While Ra was observed to influence both the nucleate boiling efficiency and CHF, rn was not capable of enhancing them both exclusively. Nonetheless, a synergistic effect of Ra and rn on the CHF was observed. The CHF values of microstructure, nanostructure, and nano/microstructure were enhanced by 19%, 9%, and 79%, respectively.
